docs.lead_paragraph: Why criticize doctors who want to provide excellent care to a small group of patients rather than cursory care to an outrageously unmanageable ''panel size of 4,200 patient lives''? Why not put the blame instead on the managed-care bureaucracy that insists its roster doctors see 24 patients a day and then spend more time handling the overwhelming paperwork? If some physicians want to opt out of this unsatisfying situation, I say kudos to them for refusing to bow down to a dangerously demoralizing system. Let the H.M.O.'s answer for the plight of patients who can no longer afford quality care. Rina Kleege New York
docs.abstract: Rina Kleege letter on Devin Friedman's May 5 article defends doctors who want to provide excellent care to small group of patients instead of accepting demand from managed-care bureaucracy that they see many patients daily and handle overwhelming paperwork

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are no shareholder proxy contests, poison-pill defenses, white-knight saviors or bear-hug tender offers. But behind a veneer of civility, two corporations are battling for dominance in the association of Blue Cross Blue Shield plans, a colossus that manages the health care of one in four Americans. The antagonists, WellPoint Health Networks and Anthem Inc., are profit-making, shareholder-owned corporations formed from parts of the original, nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield network, a group born out of social need for affordable care during the Depression.

headline.main: Battling, Politely, for Health Care's Biggest Prize

docs.abstract: WellPoint Health Networks and Anthem Inc, both for-profit shareholder-owned corporations formed from parts of original nonprofit Blue Cross Blue Shield network, are battling behind veneer of civility for network dominance; between them, they own Blue Cross Blue Shield plans in 11 states and are vying for much of what remains, over 60 million customers and 40 successful plans; critics say takeovers are adding to health care costs for some customer; consumers have been shifting from highly restrictive managed-care health plans to less restrictive Blue Cross Blue Shield plans, making plans takeover targets; takeovers by health plans outside Blue Cross Blue Shield association are nearly impossible, leaving insiders WellPoint and Anthem as only acquirers; map shows status of plans in various states; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After Success Story, A Brutal Relapse It was a real-life story heavy on hopefulness and headed for Hollywood. Then the reality turned tragic. In the 1980's, Michael B. Laudor, an employee of a management consulting firm in his 20's, began experiencing symptoms of schizophrenia, which became so acute that he was hospitalized for eight months. Afterward, with medication and therapy, he was able to enter Yale Law School, where he excelled, graduating in 1992.
docs.abstract: Michael Laudor, who pleaded not responsible because of mental disease in death of his fiancee Caroline Costello, remains hospitalized in psychiatric facility in New York; litigation between families over Costello's life insurance and retirement benefits was recently settled; Jeannette Watson, former owner of Books & Company bookstore in Manhattan, is back in book business, having bought Lenox Hill Bookstore; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DANIEL E. O'NEILL, the new mayor of Buchanan, does not scare easily when it comes to the Indian Point nuclear power plant here. Bring up the troubled history of leaks and safety lapses, and he counters that it is still cleaner than coal, and that it keeps electricity prices down. Mention terrorism, and he points to the increased security at the plant since Sept. 11. And what about the dangers of radioactive waste? Mr. O'Neill tells you that he is not worried, not even a little, by the spent fuel from the reactors, which are kept on site in turquoise pools cordoned off by ropes. He was even chided for getting too close during a recent tour of the plant. ''I didn't see the rope and leaned forward,'' he said. ''They said back up.''
docs.abstract: Article on newly elected Mayor Daniel O'Neill of Buchanan, NY, who staunchly defends Indian Point nuclear power plant despite growing opposition spurred by fears of terrorist attack; O'Neill and most village residents side with Entergy Corp and plant workers in seeking to undermine or discredit efforts by politicians, environmentalists and others to shut plant; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At a camp in Fishkill, N.Y., a group of teenagers were surrounded by woods and wildlife. But an assistant camp counselor was rehearsing them in survival skills that had little to do with nature -- unless it was the nature of growing up. As six of the teenagers sat in a circle inside a pine-scented cabin, the counselor, Tony Fong, posed a question: ''What will you have to pay for if you live on your own?''

headline.main: The Fresh Air Fund; At Camp, Survival Skills Include a Solid Résumé

docs.abstract: Fresh Air Fund appeal; Camp Mariah in Fishkill, NY, has strong focus on continuing education, careers and decision-making; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Damaged Care'' makes its point early on. Dr. Linda Peeno (Laura Dern) takes an emergency telephone call from a surgeon. A heart donor has been found, the patient is on the table and the doctor is ready to perform the transplant. All that's needed now is the insurance O.K. And Dr. Peeno, the managed care company's medical reviewer, has to make the decision. Pressured by her boss, she finds a fine-print loophole and denies coverage. The surgeon is outraged. ''You know, I believe you and your people are murderers,'' he tells her with no uncertain emotion. ''You just served a death sentence, Dr. Peeno, on a man whose life I could have saved.''

headline.main: From Insurance Denier to Health Care Crusader

docs.abstract: Anita Gates reviews Showtime television movie Damaged Care, with Laura Dern; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Bush, in Berlin, Equates Terror and Totalitarianism President Bush told Germany's Parliament that terror groups constitute a ''new totalitarian threat'' and, in a clear reference to Hitler, he compared the current struggle against such groups to a past generation's battle against those who ''killed in the name of racial purity.'' A1 Mr. Bush arrived in Moscow for a three-day visit to Russia that both sides have cast as the final eulogy to the cold war. A12

docs.lead_paragraph: Lachlan Murdoch, the son and possible corporate heir of the News Corporation chairman, Rupert Murdoch, is becoming the publisher of The New York Post, succeeding Ken Chandler, who has been a top executive at The Post since 1993. The move does little to change Lachlan Murdoch's authority -- he and his father are currently The Post's co-chairmen -- but it fills a vacancy created by the departure of Mr. Chandler, one of the last remaining senior Post executives who was not appointed by the younger Mr. Murdoch.

headline.main: Murdoch's Son Assumes Role Of Publisher at New York Post

docs.abstract: Lachlan Murdoch, son and possible corporate heir of News Corp chairman, Rupert Murdoch, is becoming publisher of New York Post, succeeding Ken Chandler, one of last remaining Post executives who was not appointed by younger Murdoch; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate tonight passed a broad trade bill that would give President Bush the authority to reach trade agreements that are largely immune from Congressional tinkering but would greatly increase aid to workers who lose their jobs because of foreign competition. The 66-to-30 vote brought the White House close to a top legislative priority that administration officials say will make it easier to expand trade, allowing Mr. Bush to reach trade accords that Congress could accept or reject, but not amend.

headline.main: Senate Approves Bill Giving Wider Trade Authority to Bush

docs.abstract: Senate passes broad trade bill that would give Pres Bush authority to reach trade agreements that are largely immune from Congressional tinkering but would greatly increase aid to workers who lose their jobs because of foreign competition; House and Senate conferees must now try to reconcile substantially different versions of bill in negotiations that will pit Democratic demands for more worker protection against Republican preferences to limit costly welfare provisions; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York Democrats tried yesterday to generate some excitement for their party and the coming election, but Andrew M. Cuomo's decision to skip the party's convention threw a long shadow over the political theatrics. Party leaders had drafted James Carville, the colorful speaker and former campaign strategist for President Bill Clinton, to inspire the 353 delegates and hundreds of elected officials who came to the Sheraton New York Hotel in Manhattan for a gathering whose outcome was largely preordained.
docs.abstract: Andrew Cuomo's decision to skip Democratic Party's state convention casts long shadow of political theatrics; photo of H Carl McCall at convention (M)
